Mammalian hair, also referred to as pelage, exhibits a range of colors that can differ among populations, individuals within a population, and even within the same individual. Variability in light and dark hues is prevalent across mammalian groups. While age can sometimes dictate color variation, other factors also play a role. Selective pressures, such as interactions with other populations and environmental circumstances, often drive color diversity in mammals. These pressures promote specific colors to enhance survival chances. Camouflage is believed to be a significant force shaping mammalian coloration, although sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes are also suggested to impact color evolution. Camouflage stands out as the primary mechanism driving color diversity.

Education holds immense importance in the national culture of Israel, deeply rooted in its historical significance dating back to Ancient Israel. It was considered a cornerstone of ancient Israelite life, and this perspective has continued to shape Israeli culture's perception of higher education as a vital tool for social and economic advancement. The value placed on education in Israeli society can be traced back to the Jewish diaspora during the Renaissance and Enlightenment Movement, leading up to the foundations of Zionism in the 1880s. Early Jewish communities in the Levant were pioneers in introducing compulsory education, underscoring the community's collective responsibility, alongside parents, for nurturing the education of future generations. The contemporary Jewish culture in Israel places a strong emphasis on fostering scholarship, intellectual pursuits, and academic achievement, reflecting the society's profound appreciation for higher education. The nation's remarkable university attainment rate further underscores the significant regard Israeli society holds for advanced education. Consequently, the Israeli education system has garnered widespread acclaim for its emphasis on academic excellence.

The main student newspaper at Northwestern University is The Daily Northwestern, which was established in 1881. Published on weekdays during the academic year, the newspaper is run entirely by undergraduates and is financially supported by advertisers, not by the university. The Students Publishing Company owns the newspaper. North by Northwestern, an online undergraduate magazine, was founded in September 2006 by students from the Medill School of Journalism. It is updated with news stories and special events throughout the day on weekdays, as well as on weekends, and also produces a quarterly print magazine. Syllabus, the undergraduate yearbook, was first published in 1885 and offers a comprehensive overview of the year's events at Northwestern. It is published by the Students Publishing Company and edited by Northwestern students, with distribution taking place in late May. Northwestern Flipside, an undergraduate satirical magazine, was established in 2009.

After the fall of Wu and the upheaval caused by the Wu Hu rebellion against the Jin dynasty (265–420), many prominent Chinese families aligned themselves with the non-Chinese rulers in the north. Some faced a loss of social status and sought sanctuary south of the Yangtze River. Refugees from northern China likely settled in areas around Hangzhou. For instance, the descendants of Zhuge Liang (181–234), a notable chancellor of the state of Shu Han in north China during the Three Kingdoms era, established Zhuge Village (Zhege Cun) on the outskirts of Hangzhou. This village, inhabited exclusively by individuals bearing the surname "Zhuge," intentionally remained secluded from neighboring communities for centuries until recently when its existence became public knowledge. This suggests that a select group of influential Chinese refugees from the Central Plain may have sought asylum there.

The '98 season started on a sad note with the passing of the iconic announcer Harry Caray. Following Sandberg's retirement and Dunston's trade, the Cubs needed to fill gaps. The arrival of Henry Rodríguez, fondly called "H-Rod," to bat cleanup provided lineup support for Sammy Sosa, with Rodriguez hitting 31 homers in his debut season in Chicago. Kevin Tapani excelled with a personal best of 19 victories, Rod Beck solidified the bullpen, and Mark Grace had a standout year. The Cubs attracted significant media attention in 1998, with Sosa and rookie pitcher Kerry Wood as the main attractions. Wood's standout moment was pitching a one-hitter against the Houston Astros, tying the MLB record of 20 strikeouts in a single game. His impressive strikeout performance earned him the nickname "Kid K" and the 1998 NL Rookie of the Year accolade. Sosa's shining moment came in June, setting a new MLB record with 20 home runs in a single month.

In modern society, adolescents encounter various risks during the transition of their sexuality. While some, like emotional distress (fear of abuse or exploitation) and sexually transmitted infections/diseases (STIs/STDs) such as HIV/AIDS, are not exclusive to adolescence, others like teenage pregnancy (resulting from non-use or failure of contraceptives) are viewed as societal concerns in many western cultures. Statistics show that one out of four sexually active teenagers will contract an STI. In the United States, teenagers often opt for activities other than intercourse under the misconception that it decreases the chances of STIs. Healthcare providers nationwide are noticing an increase in cases of herpes and human papillomavirus (HPV), which can lead to genital warts, with an estimated impact on 15 percent of individuals.

Throughout the South Slavs' history, the vernacular, literary, and written languages, such as Chakavian, Kajkavian, and Shtokavian, evolved and diverged independently based on different regions and ethnic groups. Before the 19th century, they were collectively known as "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian", or "Croatian". The term Serbo-Croatian was first introduced by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following years, and officially acknowledged by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. During that period, Serb and Croat territories were under the rule of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. The language was officially referred to as Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. Unofficially, Serbs and Croats commonly identified the language as "Serbian" or "Croatian" respectively, without implying a distinction between the two. Additionally, in independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, "Bosnian", "Croatian", and "Serbian" were recognized as three names for a single language.

Identity development is a crucial phase during adolescence when individuals typically embark on a quest to establish their sense of self. This exploration often involves experimenting with various behaviors and appearances to determine their true identity. Essentially, adolescents tend to experiment with different identities before settling on the one that resonates most with them. However, the journey of shaping and upholding one's identity during adolescence is complex, influenced by factors like family dynamics, surroundings, and social standing. Research indicates that this process is better characterized as identity development rather than formation, highlighting a natural evolution in both the substance and framework of one's identity.

Similar to Egypt, the vast Seleucid Empire was primarily influenced by a Greco-Macedonian ruling class. The Greek populace in the urban centers, constituting the dominant class, was augmented by immigrants from Greece. Notable cities like Antioch, the Syrian tetrapolis, Seleucia, and Dura-Europos were among those established, maintaining Greek city-state structures such as assemblies and councils. Nevertheless, these institutions merely masked the control exercised by Seleucid officials. In addition to these urban centers, the Seleucids strategically positioned garrisons, military settlements, and Greek villages across the empire to solidify their authority. This 'Greco-Macedonian' demographic, along with

Multiple implications arise as various research traditions are increasingly adopting the identity framework to investigate different phenomena. One notable implication pertains to identity and its role in occupational environments, particularly in challenging or stigmatized jobs, also known as "dirty work" (Hughes, 1951). Tracy and Trethewey (2005) emphasize that individuals are drawn to or deterred from specific jobs based on how well these roles align with their desired self-image within the organization. Different jobs carry varying degrees of stigma or prestige. For instance, Tracy discusses correctional officers' efforts to combat the perception of being mere "glorified maids" (Tracy & Tretheway 2005). This process involves individuals rationalizing and assigning value to their career choices, influencing aspects such as job satisfaction and overall well-being (Tracy & Scott 2006).

Emotions play a crucial role in driving social interactions and relationships, closely intertwined with fundamental physiology, especially the stress mechanisms. The connection between emotions and the anti-stress system, including the oxytocin-attachment system, is significant as it greatly influences bonding. The temperaments of emotional phenotypes impact social bonding and adaptability within intricate social structures (Kurt Kortschal 2013). These traits are not unique to humans but are also present in various species and biological classifications, attributed to genetic influences and their perpetuation over generations. Genetic codes in DNA sequences contain instructions for producing proteins that form our cells, with zygotes inheriting genetic material from parental germ cells. Throughout evolution, heritable characteristics that have promoted the survival of ancestral species are preserved and passed on.

Stanley Schachter built upon the research of Spanish physician Gregorio Marañón, who administered epinephrine to patients and gauged their subsequent emotional responses. Marañón observed that although the patients felt something, they struggled to pinpoint the source of their emotions without a clear external trigger. Schachter concurred with the significance of physiological responses in emotions, proposing that these reactions assist in directing cognitive assessments of arousing situations. He posited that emotions resulted from a twofold process: initial physiological arousal and subsequent emotional experience. To illustrate, encountering a bear in the kitchen triggers a physiological response like a racing heart, setting the stage for the ensuing emotional reaction.

The political unrest persisted, prompting John to consider forming an alliance with the recently returned French king Philip II, who had just come back from the crusade. John's aim was to secure Normandy, Anjou, and Richard's other French territories by joining forces with Philip. However, his mother advised him against pursuing this partnership. Longchamp, who had previously left England due to Walter's interference, made a comeback and contended that his removal as justiciar was unjust. John intervened, rejecting Longchamp's claims in exchange for support from the royal administration, which included a reiteration of his status as the throne's heir. With Richard still absent following the crusade, John started insinuating that his brother might be deceased or permanently lost. Unbeknownst to John, Richard had actually been captured on his way back to England by the Duke of Austria and was later handed over to Emperor Henry VI for ransom. John seized this opportunity and took action.

In the beginning, Early Modern universities maintained the educational and research practices of the Middle Ages which encompassed natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy (including astrology), law, grammar, and rhetoric. The teachings heavily featured Aristotle, with medicine also drawing from Galen and Arabic knowledge. The role of humanism in revolutionizing this traditional setup was paramount. Following the inclusion of humanist educators in university staff, there was a shift towards refining the study of grammar and rhetoric under the studia humanitatis. These professors emphasized students' proficiency in writing, speaking eloquently, translating and interpreting classical works, and leading ethical lives. The influence of humanist methodologies and linguistic abilities on other scholars within the university, concerning ancient texts, as well as the ideology emphasizing the significance of those texts, was profound. Even medical professors like Niccolò Leoniceno, Thomas Linacre, and William Cop often adopted and imparted teachings from a humanist standpoint.

Democratic Party candidates consistently won local elections, strengthening the city's connection to the South and its prevailing political faction. In 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood urged the aldermen to proclaim independence from Albany and the United States following the South's secession, though no action was taken. Outrage over the Civil War-era military draft laws, which exempted wealthier individuals who could afford a $300 commutation fee to hire substitutes, sparked the 1863 Draft Riots. Primarily involving working-class Irish immigrants, the riots escalated into violence against New York's upper class and later against black residents, stemming from intense competition between Irish newcomers and African Americans for employment opportunities. The rioters set fire to the Colored Orphan Asylum, yet over 200 children were saved from harm thanks to the swift actions of the rescuers.

However, in the mid-18th century, during the era of the French Enlightenment, a more conceptual interpretation of the term began to emerge. In 1765, an unidentified writer in a French Enlightenment magazine mentioned "The widespread love for humanity... a quality previously unnamed among us, which we shall refer to as 'humanism,' as the time has arrived to coin a term for such a splendid and crucial concept." The latter part of the 18th century and the early 19th century witnessed the establishment of numerous community-based "charitable" and compassionate organizations committed to human advancement and the dissemination of knowledge (some with Christian ties, others without). Following the French Revolution, the notion that human goodness could be fostered through human intellect alone, separate from conventional religious establishments, a belief ascribed by critics of the Revolution to Enlightenment thinkers like Rousseau, was fiercely debated.

The outcome consisted of a series of inventive yet unpopular financial actions. John imposed scutage dues a total of eleven times during his seventeen-year rule, a stark contrast to the cumulative occurrences under the prior three rulers. Many times, these impositions happened without an ongoing military conflict, deviating from the original purpose of scutage as a substitute for actual military duty. John exploited his authority to collect relief payments upon inheritance of estates and castles, occasionally demanding exorbitant amounts that exceeded the financial capacity of the barons. Following the profitable sale of sheriff positions in 1194, John introduced a fresh round of appointments, enabling the new appointees to recoup their investment through escalated fines and penalties, especially within the forest regions. He also expanded Richard's initiative of heightened fees imposed on widows who chose to remain unmarried. Additionally, John persisted in the practice of selling charters for establishing new towns, including.

During the Enlightenment, new concepts regarding religion emerged, such as Deism and discussions on atheism. Deism, as explained by Thomas Paine, is the belief in a single God as the Creator, without relying on the Bible or miracles, but rather on personal reasoning. This perspective found favor among many intellectuals of that era. While atheism was a topic of debate, it had limited proponents. Wilson and Reill suggest that most enlightened thinkers critical of Christianity were not true atheists but rather inclined towards skepticism, deism, vitalism, or pantheism. Some, inspired by Pierre Bayle, argued that atheists could uphold moral principles. Others, like Voltaire, contended that without belief in a punishing God, society's moral fabric would weaken due to atheists not recognizing a supreme authority or moral code.

Sleep does not impact the acquisition or recall of information while one is awake, with its primary influence being on memory consolidation. During sleep, the brain's neural connections are reinforced, enhancing its capacity to stabilize and preserve memories. Numerous studies have demonstrated that sleep plays a crucial role in enhancing memory retention through active consolidation. The process of system consolidation occurs during slow-wave sleep (SWS), during which memories are reactivated and transferred to long-term storage, although not all memories are equally enhanced. This process also involves qualitative modifications to memories as they are moved to long-term memory during sleep. As one sleeps, the hippocampus replays the day's events for the neocortex, which then reviews and processes memories for long-term storage. Insufficient sleep weakens neural connections, making learning more challenging and resulting in reduced memory retention.

Memory does not function like a passive recording device, as commonly believed. The molecular processes involved in creating and retaining memories are intricate and involve distinct phases that can span from seconds to a lifetime. Studies have shown that memories are not exact replicas of events but rather are constructed. This construction occurs during the encoding and retrieval stages of memory. For instance, a study by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) demonstrated how the phrasing of questions can influence memory recall. Participants who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" gave higher speed estimates compared to those asked, "How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?" Furthermore, when questioned a week later about seeing broken glass in the film, participants who had heard the word "smashed" were more likely to falsely recall seeing broken glass.

Zhejiang in ancient times was not under the strong influence of the Shang civilization in the second millennium BC. Instead, it was inhabited by various groups collectively referred to as the Hundred Yue, which included the Dongyue and the Ouyue. Historical accounts from the Spring and Autumn Period mention the emergence of the kingdom of Yue in northern Zhejiang. According to ancient records, the rulers of Yue were believed to be descendants of Yu the Great, the founder of the Shang dynasty. The Baiyue people and the kingdom of Yue are believed to have had unique cultural and historical backgrounds distinct from the kingdoms in northern and central China, which had detailed records of their cultures and histories during the Spring and Autumn Period and the Qin dynasty. One of the notable references to this is the "Song of the Yue Boatman" (Chinese: 越人歌, p Yuèrén Gē, lit. "Song").

Protestantism extended from German territories to France, where adherents were known as Huguenots. Calvin, operating from Geneva, maintained interest in French religious matters and trained pastors for local congregations. Despite severe persecution, the Reformed movement gained ground in various parts of France, attracting those disillusioned by the rigidity and inaction of the Catholic establishment. French Protestantism evolved into a politically charged movement, especially evident with the conversion of nobles in the 1550s, setting the stage for the French Wars of Religion. These conflicts escalated following the sudden death of Henry II of France in 1559, characterized by atrocities and violence, culminating in the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre in August 1572, where the Roman Catholic faction massacred tens of thousands of Huguenots in France.

In comparison to other team sports, the structure of the National Football League preseason is highly organized. Each NFL team participates in four pre-season exhibition games annually, comprising two home games and two away games. Additionally, two teams are selected each year to play a fifth game known as the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. The exhibition matches, predominantly taking place in August, serve the purpose of aiding coaches in trimming the roster from the offseason cap of 90 players to the regular-season cap of 53 players. Although the scheduling of preseason games is less strict than that of regular-season games, there exist several limitations and customs that govern the selection of opponents for these matches. Moreover, teams are bound by constraints regarding the days and times at which these games can be played. A notable practice observed in baseball and hockey, split-squad games, involves a team dividing its players into two squads when scheduled to play two games on the same day.

During the early and mid-1980s, Libya faced economic challenges with a significant decline in annual oil revenues from $21 billion in 1982 to $5.4 billion in 1986. In an effort to boost the economy, construction commenced on the ambitious Great Man-Made River project in 1983, a venture spearheaded by Muammar Gaddafi. Despite initial plans for completion by the end of the decade, the project remained unfinished as the new century began. Meanwhile, military expenditures surged while cuts were made to other government budgets. Libya's involvement in Chad's civil war included supporting the FROLINAT militia, leading to a re-invasion of Chad in December 1980 at the behest of the Frolinat-controlled GUNT government. Gaddafi proposed a political merger in January 1981, which was rejected by the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), prompting a Libyan withdrawal in November 1981. The conflict in Chad reignited, prompting Libya to dispatch troops again, resulting in clashes with French forces supporting the southern Chadian factions.

In Seoul, South Korea, on April 27, an event took place where designated torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun opted out in objection to the Chinese government's actions in Tibet. To ensure security along the 24-kilometre relay route starting at Olympic Park from the 1988 Summer Games, over 8,000 riot police were deployed. The day of the torch relay saw confrontations between Chinese students and protesters, resulting in violence with the throwing of objects and physical altercations. A North Korean defector, whose brother was executed after attempting to flee to China, tried to self-immolate in protest against China's treatment of North Korean refugees. Despite attempting to set himself on fire by dousing in gasoline, the police intervened promptly, preventing the act. Additionally, two demonstrators made unsuccessful attempts to disrupt the torch relay. Near the start of the relay, clashes emerged involving 500 Chinese supporters and a group of individuals.

The discussions surrounding the interpretations of separation by Jefferson and James Madison have persisted. During his presidency, Jefferson declined to issue Congress's Thanksgiving Proclamations but had issued a Thanksgiving and Prayer proclamation as Virginia's Governor. While Madison, as President, issued four religious proclamations, he vetoed two bills for breaching the first amendment. Despite this, both Jefferson and Madison were present at religious services held in the Capitol. Even before the Constitution's ratification, Madison argued that religion should not be under the control of society or the legislative branch. Following his presidential term, Madison advocated for the "total separation of the church from the state," emphasizing the Constitution's strong protection of the division between Religion and Government.

Virgil's works had a significant impact on Latin poetry immediately upon their release. The Eclogues, Georgics, and especially the Aeneid quickly became essential texts in the education of all well-read Romans. Poets who came after Virgil often allude to his works to add depth to their own poetry. For instance, the Augustan poet Ovid humorously mimics the beginning of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his condensed retelling of the Aeneas saga in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, dubbed the "mini-Aeneid," stands out as a notable post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan’s Bellum Civile, an epic known for its departure from Virgilian conventions by eschewing divine intervention, focusing on historical events, and straying significantly from Virgil’s epic style. The poet Statius, of the Flavian era, extensively interacts with Virgil's poetry in his 12-book epic Thebaid; in the conclusion, he cautions his work not to "compete with the divine Aeneid, but to respectfully trace its path from a distance." Silius Italicus, like Virgil, also...

According to Terry Eastland, the author of the book "From Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice," most arguments supporting affirmative action aim at rectifying past discrimination and promoting diversity. Eastland contends that the original architects of affirmative action did not foresee that its benefits would often be reaped by middle-class minorities who may not actually require it. She further posits that affirmative action can lead to a sense of self-doubt and entitlement among minorities due to the associated stigma. Eastland views affirmative action as a risky endeavor with inconsistent outcomes, suggesting that its absence could foster a more competitive environment. Libertarian economist Thomas Sowell, in his work "Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study," identifies adverse effects of affirmative action, noting that these policies may prompt individuals from non-preferred groups to falsely identify as members of preferred groups, thereby potentially distorting the intentions of affirmative action.

The most significant military engagement that involved the United States during this period was the War of 1812. Amid Britain's conflict with Napoleon's France, it aimed to obstruct American trade with France. While the United States aimed to stay impartial and continue international trade, Britain disrupted trade and pressed American sailors into the Royal Navy, sparking strong objections. Furthermore, Britain backed a Native American uprising in the American Midwest to establish a Native American state that would impede American westward expansion. This led to the United States declaring war on the United Kingdom in 1812, marking its first official declaration of war. Acknowledging the challenge of facing the powerful Royal Navy, the U.S. strategy involved invading British Canada in the hopes of using captured land as leverage. The Canadian invasion proved disastrous, although simultaneous conflicts with Native Americans in the west, such as Tecumseh's War and the Creek War, saw more success. Following Napoleon's defeat in 1814, Britain deployed seasoned armies to invade.

In relation to these peripheral areas, the Qing dynasty retained imperial authority, with the emperor assuming the roles of Mongol khan, supporter of Tibetan Buddhism, and guardian of Muslims. Nonetheless, Qing strategy shifted following the establishment of Xinjiang province in 1884. Amid The Great Game period, seizing the opportunity presented by the Dungan rebellion in northwestern China, Yaqub Beg invaded Xinjiang from Central Asia with backing from the British Empire, proclaiming himself ruler of the Kashgaria kingdom. The Qing administration dispatched troops to quell Yaqub Beg, resulting in the reconquest of Xinjiang and the formal imposition of China's political framework on the region. The Kumul Khanate, integrated into the Qing empire as a vassal following its assistance in defeating the Zunghars in 1757, retained its autonomy post Xinjiang's provincial transformation until the demise of the dynasty during the Xinhai Revolution in 1930. In the early 20th century, Britain launched a military expedition to Tibet, compelling the Tibetans to conform to their demands.

BYU boasts 21 NCAA varsity teams, with 19 of them primarily competing in the Mountain West Conference from 1999 until the school's departure in 2011. Before that, the teams participated in the Western Athletic Conference. All the teams are known as the "Cougars," and the school's mascot, Cosmo the Cougar, has represented them since 1953. The Cougar Fight Song serves as the school's anthem. Due to many players undertaking two-year full-time missions (men at 18, women at 19), BYU athletes tend to be older on average compared to peers from other institutions. The NCAA allows students to go on missions for two years without affecting their eligibility. Although this practice has sparked some controversy, it's generally accepted that it doesn't give the school a significant advantage since players don't receive athletic training during their missions. BYU has also made headlines for its stance on refusing to compete in games on certain dates.

John saw the interdict as a severe act akin to a declaration of war by the Pope. In response, he endeavored to retaliate against Innocent personally and sow discord among English clergy supporting the Pope and those backing the English authorities. John confiscated the lands of clergy who refused to perform services, including properties associated with Innocent. He apprehended the mistresses of clergy, releasing them upon payment of fines, seized the estates of church members who fled the country, and assured protection for clergy loyal to him. Some institutions could negotiate terms to manage their properties and retain profits. By 1209, the deadlock persisted, with Innocent threatening to excommunicate John unless he accepted Langton's appointment. When this ultimatum was ineffective, Innocent

In China, the 3rd, 6th, and 40th Divisions of the Japanese army gathered at Yueyang in mainland China and proceeded southward in three groups, crossing the Xinqiang River. Their objective was to cross the Miluo River to reach Changsha. However, in January 1942, Chinese troops achieved a significant victory at Changsha, marking the first success for the Allies against Japan. Following the Doolittle Raid, the Japanese military launched a large-scale operation in Zhejiang and Jiangxi provinces in China, which became known as the Zhejiang-Jiangxi Campaign. The primary goals were to locate the surviving American airmen, punish the Chinese who assisted them, and eliminate air bases. This offensive commenced on May 15, 1942, with 40 infantry battalions and 15–16 artillery battalions. Nonetheless, Chinese forces successfully fended off the Japanese advance by September. Throughout this campaign, the Imperial Japanese Army inflicted widespread destruction and chaos in the region.

According to CNET, the new Super Slim PlayStation 3 received a rating of 4 out of 5 stars, described as "Excellent." The review highlighted that the compact design of the Super Slim PS3 successfully retains the powerful gaming capabilities and features of its predecessors, including an extensive gaming library and a wide range of streaming services. However, CNET criticized the perceived "cheap" quality of the design and disc-loader mechanism, likening it to old credit card imprinters and expressing a preference for autoloading disc trays. The review also pointed out that despite the smaller size and larger hard drive of the Super Slim model, it was seen as a drawback as the hard drive in the Slim model could be easily swapped out. Additionally, the review noted that the pricing of the Super Slim model was higher than the Slim model, suggesting that the enhanced features may not justify the increased cost.

Dorgon's controversial decree in July 1645, known as the "haircutting order," mandated that adult Han Chinese men shave the front of their heads and style the remaining hair into the queue, a hairstyle worn by Manchu men, under the threat of death. This directive was succinctly summarized as: "To keep the hair, you lose the head; To keep your head, you cut the hair." For the Manchus, the edict served as a loyalty test and a means of identifying allies and enemies. Conversely, for the Han Chinese population, it represented a degrading imposition of Qing authority that clashed with their ingrained Confucian beliefs. According to the Classic of Filial Piety (Xiaojing), which emphasized the sanctity of one's body and hair as parental gifts, altering one's hair was deemed unacceptable. During the Ming dynasty, adult men maintained their hair long instead of adhering to the mandated hairstyle.

Boundaries can be either inclusive or exclusive, depending on how they are perceived by others. For instance, an exclusive boundary is established when an individual sets a restriction through a marker that limits the actions of others. Conversely, an inclusive boundary is formed when a marker is used that others are willing and able to connect with. Yet, an inclusive boundary also restricts those included by confining their inclusion in other boundaries. For instance, when a newcomer in a multilingual gathering uses a specific language, some attendees may comprehend it while others may not. Those who do not understand the language might interpret its use as a neutral expression of identity or as an exclusive boundary meant to differentiate them from the newcomer.

During the era of 78 rpm records, manufacturers experimented with novel materials to create flexible or "unbreakable" records. In the UK, Nicole records, composed of celluloid or a similar substance layered onto a cardboard core disc, were introduced in 1904 but were plagued by excessive surface noise issues. In the United States, Columbia Records launched the flexible fiber-cored "Marconi Velvet Tone Record" in 1907, which promised a quieter surface with the use of special gold-plated Marconi Needles, but it failed to gain popularity. Thin, bendable plastic records like the German Phonycord and British Filmophone and Goodson records emerged around 1930 but had short lifespans. The French Pathé Cellodiscs, crafted from a thin black plastic, bore a striking resemblance to the traditional shellac records of the time.

In 1919, after the Treaty of Versailles, the city was returned to France without a plebiscite, following U.S. President Woodrow Wilson's "Fourteen Points." The official transfer took place on Armistice Day. The outcome of a potential referendum in Strasbourg favoring France remains uncertain, as political factions advocating for an independent Alsace or alignment with France held minimal influence in both the last Reichstag and local elections. Pro-French Alsatian autonomists garnered significant support in rural areas and other municipalities following the region's annexation by Germany in 1871. The movement commenced during the initial Reichstag election, with the elected representatives known as "les députés protestataires." These delegates remained the sole Alsatian representatives in the German parliament until Bismarck's downfall in 1890.

While Western Europe saw the emergence of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained undivided and underwent an economic resurgence until the early 7th century. The Eastern part faced fewer invasions, primarily in the Balkans, and maintained peace with Persia for most of the 5th century. A distinct feature of the Eastern Empire was the close relationship between the government and the Christian Church, where doctrinal issues played a significant role in politics, unlike in Western Europe. Legal advancements included the codification of Roman law, starting with the completion of the Theodosian Code in 438. Emperor Justinian (527–565) initiated another compilation, the Corpus Juris Civilis, and oversaw the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople. During his reign, North Africa was reclaimed from the Vandals and Italy from the Ostrogoths by Belisarius (d. 565), although the conquest of Italy remained incomplete due to a severe plague outbreak in 542, leading Justinian to focus on defensive strategies for the remainder of his rule.

Upon the release of the NES in the US, Nintendo intentionally opted for a distinct design approach compared to other gaming consoles. The aim was to set their product apart from competitors and break away from the negative perception that game consoles had garnered post the 1983 video game crash. As part of this strategy, Nintendo concealed the cartridge slot as a front-loading zero insertion force (ZIF) cartridge socket, cleverly resembling a VCR's front-loading mechanism. While this innovative connector functioned effectively with clean components, prolonged use led to the bending of contact pins and the ROM board within the cartridge due to the force applied when inserting the cartridge. With continuous cartridge insertions and removals, the pins suffered wear and tear over time, challenging the ZIF connector's longevity.

Protestants were pioneers in advocating for religious freedom, with a strong emphasis on freedom of conscience following Luther's stand at the Diet of Worms in 1521. Luther believed faith was a personal choice guided by the Holy Spirit and could not be imposed. Anabaptists and Huguenots who faced persecution also pushed for freedom of conscience and upheld the separation of church and state. Baptists such as John Smyth and Thomas Helwys defended religious freedom in the early 17th century, influencing later thinkers like John Milton and John Locke. Leaders like Roger Williams, Thomas Hooker, and William Penn established democratic colonies in Rhode Island, Connecticut, and Pennsylvania, respectively, with provisions for religious freedom. These colonies welcomed persecuted religious groups, including Jews, and laid the groundwork for the principles enshrined in the United States Declaration of Independence, Constitution, and Bill of Rights.

Birds possess a highly effective oxygen diffusion system in their blood, with a gas exchange surface area ten times larger compared to mammals. This results in a higher concentration of blood in their capillaries per lung volume unit than in mammals. The arteries are built with robust elastic muscles to endure ventricular pressure and gradually stiffen away from the heart. Blood flows through the arteries, experiencing vasoconstriction, and then enters arterioles that function as a distribution network for oxygen and nutrients to all body tissues. Arterioles branch out further from the heart into organs and tissues, dividing to enhance surface area and regulate blood flow. Within the capillaries, located in organized beds within tissues, gas exchange takes place.

The men's basketball team boasts a remarkable record of over 1,600 wins, a feat achieved by only 12 schools, along with 28 appearances in NCAA tournaments. Notably, former player Austin Carr set a tournament record by scoring 61 points in a single game. While the team has never clinched an NCAA Tournament victory, they were honored twice as national champions by the Helms Athletic Foundation. Renowned for their upsets of top-ranked teams, their most famous triumph was halting UCLA's historic 88-game winning streak in 1974. They have defeated eight more number-one teams, trailing only UCLA's ten victories in this category. Competing at the revamped Purcell Pavilion in the Edmund P. Joyce Center since the 2009–2010 season, the team is under the guidance of coach Mike Brey, who has led them since the 2014–15 season.

A century following the conquest of Constantinople in 1453, Pierre Belon documented in his publication Observations in 1553 that a substance called pissasphalto, a blend of pitch and bitumen, was utilized in Dubrovnik for coating ships and later traded in the Venetian market. The usage of asphalt in France was reported in an 1838 edition of Mechanics Magazine. A pamphlet dated 1621 by "a certain Monsieur d'Eyrinys" mentioned the discovery of abundant asphaltum near Neufchatel and proposed various applications, notably in constructing airtight silos and safeguarding Paris waterways from contamination with arches.

Established in 1852, Marshall Field & Company was the leading department store situated on State Street in Chicago, the primary shopping hub in the Midwest. Drawing in affluent customers from all over the region who arrived by train and stayed at nearby hotels, it expanded into a prominent chain before rebranding as Macy's on 9 September 2006. Marshall Field's was renowned for its exceptional customer service, setting a benchmark for other department stores. It introduced the iconic Frango mints, closely associated with both Marshall Field's and Chicago, acquired from the now-defunct Frederick & Nelson Department Store. Pioneering several innovations, Marshall Field's housed the first European buying office in Manchester, England, and initiated the concept of the bridal registry. It was also the first to offer personal shoppers, a complimentary service available in all Field's stores until the chain's closure.

Certain street trams utilized conduit third-rail technology for power collection, with the third rail positioned below street level. The tram accessed the current using a plough (known as a plow in the U.S.) through a narrow slot in the road surface. In the United States, a significant portion of Washington, D.C.'s former streetcar system, discontinued in 1962, operated in this fashion to eliminate the visual clutter of overhead wires and poles typical of electric traction systems. A similar approach was taken with Manhattan's erstwhile streetcar network. Remnants of this operational method are still observable on the track leading down the incline at the northern entrance to the disused Kingsway Tramway Subway in central London, where the slot between the running rails remains visible. Additionally, traces of this system can be found on P and Q Streets to the west of Wisconsin Avenue in Washington, D.C.'s Georgetown district.

According to the 2010 Census, the Asian American population in New York City exceeds one million, surpassing the combined totals of San Francisco and Los Angeles. New York City boasts the highest number of Asian residents among all U.S. cities. Queens, a borough of New York City, is home to the largest Asian American community in the state, as well as the largest Andean populations in the country, making it one of the most ethnically diverse urban areas globally. The Chinese community is the fastest-growing nationality in New York State, with satellite Chinatowns flourishing in Brooklyn and Flushing, Queens, and expanding into suburban Nassau County on Long Island. The New York metropolitan region and the state have become primary destinations for new Chinese immigrants, leading to ongoing large-scale immigration into New York City and its vicinity. As of 2012, Chinese residents made up 6.3% of New York City's population.

In their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races," Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles offer a detailed critique of using FST in analyzing human populations. They argue that the commonly cited 85% figure for genetic diversity across human populations is misleading as it suggests equal genetic representation across all groups. Long and Kittles contend that this approach oversimplifies human population history by assuming independence among groups. They propose a more accurate perspective that acknowledges some groups as ancestral to others, creating paraphyletic relationships. For instance, according to the recent African origin theory, the African population is considered paraphyletic to non-African groups, serving as the ancestral source for the latter. However, non-African populations trace back to a limited and non-representative subset of the African population.

There was a surge in privatization in Libya's economy, with government officials rejecting the socialist principles of nationalized industries from The Green Book. They claimed to be establishing "people's socialism" rather than capitalism. Muammar Gaddafi supported these changes and called for extensive privatization in a speech in March 2003. By 2003, the oil sector had been mostly handed over to private companies, leading to a substantial increase in foreign direct investment to $40 billion by 2004, a sixfold jump from the previous year. Some segments of the Libyan population protested against these reforms, resulting in public demonstrations. In March 2006, radical revolutionaries seized control of the GPC cabinet, moderating the pace of reforms but not stopping them altogether. Plans were revealed in 2010 to privatize half of Libya's economy in the next ten years, although there was no corresponding political liberalization, and Gaddafi remained in power. Nonetheless, in March 2010, the government granted more authority to municipal councils.

Military operations commenced in September 1806, marked by the initiation of maneuvers. In a significant correspondence with Marshal Soult outlining the campaign strategy, Napoleon delineated the key principles of Napoleonic warfare and introduced the concept of the "square battalion" known as le bataillon-carré. This innovative strategy involved the synchronized marching of various Grande Armée corps in close proximity to provide mutual support. By utilizing the bataillon-carré system, if one corps came under attack, the others could swiftly come to its aid. Leading an invasion of Prussia with an army of 180,000 soldiers, Napoleon swiftly advanced along the right bank of the River Saale. His primary objective, consistent with past campaigns, was to eliminate one adversary before reinforcements from another could alter the war's outcome. Upon locating the Prussian forces, the French forces changed course to the west and crossed the Saale with superior strength. The decisive battles of Jena and Auerstedt took place on 14 October, resulting in a resounding victory for the French forces.

Many historians believe that the removal of Maxim Litvinov, who was not favored by Nazi Germany due to his Jewish background, paved the way for German-Soviet negotiations. Stalin promptly instructed Molotov to remove Jews from the ministry. Litvinov, known for his efforts to build an anti-fascist coalition, his alignment with collective security alongside France and Britain, and his relatively pro-Western stance within the Kremlin, indicated the Soviet Union's readiness to engage with Germany. Molotov's appointment signaled the USSR's openness to German propositions. Litvinov's departure also suggested to France and Britain the possibility of negotiating with Germany. A British official noted Litvinov's departure as the loss of a skilled diplomat, contrasting Molotov's approach as more in line with Bolshevik principles than traditional diplomacy. Carr highlighted the Soviet Union's shift in foreign policy with the replacement of Litvinov.

Critics characterized Gaddafi as despotic, cruel, arrogant, vain, and unintelligent, while western governments and media portrayed him as the oppressive dictator of a suffering nation. During the Reagan era, the United States viewed him as their top adversary, famously labeling him the "mad dog of the Middle East". Critics highlighted that under Gaddafi's rule, Libyans lived in constant fear due to widespread government surveillance. Gaddafi's regime was commonly referred to by western observers as a repressive regime. Critics condemned the human rights violations in Libya, with organizations like Human Rights Watch (HRW) reporting that many arrested political dissidents were denied fair trials, subjected to torture, or faced extrajudicial killings, notably in instances like the alleged massacre in Abu Salim prison on June 29, 1996.

A true predator is typically defined as an organism that hunts and consumes another living organism. While other types of predators harm their prey in various ways, this specific type causes the death of its prey. Predators may actively seek out their prey through pursuit predation or wait for the prey to come within striking distance, as seen in ambush predators. Some predators, like jaguars or humans, kill large prey, dismembering or chewing it before consumption, while others, like bottlenose dolphins or snakes, ingest their usually smaller prey whole. Animals such as domestic cats and dogs exhibit flexibility in their hunting methods, consuming large insects whole but dismembering a rabbit, depending on the circumstances. Certain predators use venom to incapacitate their prey before consuming it, ensuring the prey is killed before ingestion.

Twice in ancient history, the Israelites experienced periods of political independence, initially during the era of the Biblical judges and later in the United Monarchy.[disputed – discuss] Following the decline of the United Monarchy, the land was split into Israel and Judah. The term "Jew" originated from the Roman term "Judean," referring to individuals from the southern kingdom of Judah. This shift in the ethnonym from "Israelites" to "Jews," specifically meaning inhabitants of Judah, though not explicitly mentioned in the Torah, can be found in the Book of Esther (4th century BCE), a text within the Ketuvim, the third section of the Jewish Tanakh. In 587 BC, Nebuchadnezzar II, the King of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, laid siege to Jerusalem, demolished the First Temple, and exiled the prominent citizens of Judah. By 586 BC, Judah no longer existed as an independent kingdom, and its remaining Jewish population was left without a state. The Babylonian captivity concluded in 539 BCE when the Achaemenid Empire overtook Babylon, and Cyrus the Great

Van Praag points out that the Ming court's diplomatic relations with Tibet were primarily to acquire much-needed horses. According to Wang and Nyima, these interactions did not constitute formal diplomacy as Tibetan regions were under Ming rule, with Tibetan leaders holding positions as Ming officials. They further argue that horses were obtained from Tibet as part of a compulsory "corvée" tax, suggesting that Tibetans were dealing with internal matters rather than engaging in foreign diplomacy. Sperling adds that the Ming procured horses from the Kham region, battled Tibetan tribes in Amdo, and received Tibetan delegations in Nanjing. He suggests that the visits of Tibetan lamas to the Ming court were largely aimed at facilitating commercial exchanges between the lamas' affluent entourage and Ming Chinese traders and authorities. Kolmaš notes that although the Ming adopted a hands-off approach towards Tibet and restricted the size of Tibetan delegations, Tibetans aimed to uphold a tributary bond with the Ming due to imperial favor.

The Guangxu Emperor passed away on November 14, 1908, followed by the death of Cixi on November 15, 1908. Speculations emerged suggesting Cixi or Yuan Shikai might have instructed loyal eunuchs to poison the Guangxu Emperor, a theory validated by a post-mortem examination almost a hundred years later, which revealed toxic levels of arsenic in his remains. Puyi, the son of Zaifeng, Prince Chun, and the nephew of the childless Guangxu Emperor, was anointed as his heir at the age of two, with Zaifeng assuming the role of regent. Subsequently, General Yuan Shikai was relieved of his influential positions. In April 1911, Zaifeng established a cabinet featuring two vice-premiers. However, this cabinet was commonly referred to as "The Royal Cabinet" by contemporaries due to the fact that, within the thirteen-member cabinet, five were closely associated with the royal family.

Feathers are shed regularly through a process known as moulting in birds. The standard plumage observed in birds post-moult, following the breeding period, is referred to as the "non-breeding" or "basic" plumage according to the Humphrey-Parkes classification system. Breeding plumages, or variations of the basic plumage, are categorized as "alternate" plumages in the Humphrey-Parkes system. While most species undergo an annual moult, some may experience two moults per year, and larger birds of prey might moult only once every few years. Moulting sequences differ among species. In perching birds, or passerines, flight feathers are typically replaced one by one, starting with the innermost primary feather. As the fifth or sixth primary feather is renewed, the outermost tertiaries begin to shed. Following the moult of the innermost tertiaries, the process moves to the secondaries from the innermost outwards (centrifugal moult). The greater primary coverts shed in coordination with the primaries they cover. A few species, like

Agrarian societies emerged in southeast Europe during the 7th millennium BC, evidenced by the discovery of one of Europe's earliest farming sites in Vashtëmi, southeastern Albania, dating back to 6,500 BC. Anthropomorphic figurines dating from 6000 BC have been unearthed in the Balkans and around 5800 BC in Central Europe (La Hoguette). The Sesklo culture in Thessaly is among the earliest cultural complexes in the region, later expanding into the Balkans and giving rise to Starčevo-Körös (Cris), Linearbandkeramik, and Vinča cultures. Neolithic traditions spread westward and northward through a mix of cultural diffusion and migration, reaching northwestern Europe around 4500 BC. The Vinča culture is credited with potentially developing the earliest system of writing known as the Vinča signs, although archaeologist Shan Winn suggests that they likely functioned as pictograms and ideograms rather than a fully evolved form of writing.

Various reasons have been proposed for Yale's involvement in national elections post-Vietnam War. It is widely acknowledged that a culture of campus activism has thrived at Yale since the 1960s, influenced by Reverend William Sloane Coffin and the institution's emphasis on grooming future leaders, a tradition initiated by Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster. Richard Levin, former Yale President, links this trend to Yale's commitment to nurturing leadership potential. Richard H. Brodhead, ex-dean of Yale College and current Duke University president, highlights the university's emphasis on community engagement in its admissions process and a strong volunteerism tradition. Yale historian Gaddis Smith highlights a culture of organized activities at Yale in the 20th century, citing examples such as John Kerry, George Pataki, and Joseph Lieberman who were involved in various leadership roles during their time at Yale. Camille Paglia also underscores this historical trend.

Among major Canadian cities, St. John's stands out as the foggiest (124 days), windiest (with an average speed of 24.3 km/h (15.1 mph)), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). Despite being milder during winter compared to other Canadian cities, St. John's boasts the mildest winter of any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. The city experiences frequent and heavy precipitation year-round, with the driest season typically being summer, characterized by sporadic thunderstorm activity. Conversely, the wettest period spans from October to January, with December being the wettest month, averaging almost 165 millimetres of precipitation. This peak in winter precipitation is atypical for humid continental climates, which typically see increased precipitation in late spring or early summer.

In Paris, the torch relay on April 7 started at the Eiffel Tower's first level and concluded at the Stade Charléty, covering a planned 28 km distance. However, due to pressure from Chinese authorities amid protests by pro-Tibet and human rights activists disrupting the event, the route was shortened. A town hall ceremony was canceled at the request of Chinese officials, and the torch's final leg was completed by bus rather than by athletes. Paris City officials had intended to peacefully protest upon the torch's arrival in the French capital, displaying a banner advocating for human rights.

In Europe and the United States, green is widely associated with nature, life, health, youth, spring, hope, and envy, according to surveys conducted. Despite some negative connotations such as death, sickness, or the devil in these regions, green holds overwhelmingly positive symbolism in China, where it represents fertility and happiness. During the Middle Ages and Renaissance periods, clothing color denoted social status, with green attire being worn by merchants, bankers, and the gentry, contrasting with the association of red with nobility. Notably, in Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, the presence of green attire signifies the absence of noble lineage. Similarly, green benches in the British House of Commons juxtapose with red benches in the House of Lords. Beyond symbolism, green is universally recognized as a color denoting safety and permission, as seen in traffic lights signaling "go ahead" and green cards granting permanent residency.

The era marked Libya's re-emergence on the global stage. Starting in 1999, secret negotiations between Libya and the British government aimed at restoring diplomatic ties. By 2001, Gaddafi openly denounced the September 11 attacks, showing solidarity with the victims and advocating Libyan participation in the global War on Terror against extremist Islamism. Concurrently, his regime cracked down on domestic Islamist movements, even as he endorsed a broader implementation of sharia law. Libya also solidified relationships with China and North Korea, receiving a visit from Chinese President Jiang Zemin in April 2002. Following the aftermath of the Iraq War, Libya publicly renounced its possession of weapons of mass destruction in December 2003, dismantling its chemical and nuclear arms programs. This decision led to improved relations with the U.S., culminating in a meeting between UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and Gaddafi in the Libyan desert in March 2004. Shortly after, Gaddafi journeyed to the European Union (EU) headquarters in Brussels, marking a significant enhancement.

In 356, Constantius decreed Liberius' exile, granting him a mere three-day deadline for compliance. The ousted Liberius was directed to Beroea in Thrace and offered substantial gifts, including five hundred pieces of gold, as inducement to embrace the Arian doctrine. However, Liberius rejected the gifts, suggesting they be given to his sycophants instead. He similarly spurned a gift from the empress, urging the messenger to embrace Christianity and desist from persecuting the Church. Despite efforts to leave the offerings in the Church, Liberius discarded them. Constantius then summoned Liberius to Milan under tight security. During a documented meeting, Liberius fearlessly informed Constantius that Athanasius had been vindicated at Sardica, branding his adversaries as liars and impostors, and decrying the injustice.

Roc-A-Fella released The College Dropout in February 2004. It quickly climbed to number two on the Billboard 200, with the lead single "Through the Wire" reaching number fifteen on the Billboard Hot 100 for five weeks. The second single, "Slow Jamz", a collaboration with Twista and Jamie Foxx, achieved even greater success by becoming the trio's first number one hit. The album garnered widespread critical acclaim, earning the title of the top album of the year from two major music publications. The track "Jesus Walks", the fourth single from the album, touched on themes of faith and Christianity, exposing West to a broader audience. Despite industry skepticism due to its religious content, the song managed to break into the top 20 of the Billboard pop charts.

The Montana Territory was established on April 26, 1864, following the enactment of the Organic Act by the U.S. Even before its official designation as a territory, the region saw the emergence of schools as families began to settle there. Initially, subscription schools were prevalent, often conducted in the teacher's residence. One of the earliest documented formal schools was established at Fort Owen in Bitterroot Valley in 1862, catering to Indian children and the offspring of Fort Owen staff members. The school term commenced in early winter, concluding by February 28, under the guidance of Mr. Robinson. Another subscription school, founded by Thomas Dimsdale, operated in Virginia City in 1863, requiring students to pay $1.75 weekly. In 1864, the Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly convened for the first time and endorsed county tax levies for schools, laying the groundwork for public education.

Self-esteem, a crucial element in identity development, encompasses one's perceptions and emotions regarding their self-concept and sense of self. Various theories emphasize the universal inclination, irrespective of age or gender, to safeguard, boost, and preserve self-esteem. Despite common belief, there is no substantial proof of a notable decline in self-esteem during adolescence. Though "barometric self-esteem" may fluctuate rapidly, triggering distress and anxiety, underlying self-esteem generally remains constant throughout adolescence. Criticisms have been raised concerning the reliability of global self-esteem assessments, with suggestions that more targeted scales could offer deeper insights into the adolescent psyche. For girls, nurturing relationships with friends play a pivotal role in fostering high self-esteem, with the core purpose of friendship often revolving around the provision of social and moral support.

The deeper ancestral demographics of Bermuda's population have been concealed due to the ethnic blending over the past four centuries. The distinction between black and white Bermudians is almost non-existent, except for recent immigrant groups. In contrast, during the 17th century, the population composition was quite different. Initially, white Protestants of English descent dominated the settlement for the first century, with smaller white communities of Irish and Scots who were sent to Bermuda post the English invasions of their countries following the English Civil War. Among the non-white minorities were Spanish-speaking free blacks from the West Indies, black slaves mainly seized from Spanish and Portuguese ships by Bermudian privateers, and Native Americans, primarily from Algonquian and other tribes along the Atlantic coast, possibly even from as far as Mexico. As the 19th century approached, the numerical superiority of white Bermudians of English descent dwindled.

Intel had made efforts to persuade Apple to switch the Macintosh platform to Intel chips, but Apple declined due to concerns about Intel's CISC architecture being unable to rival RISC processors. Although the Motorola 68040 could outperform the Intel 80486 in certain aspects, the 486 could achieve higher clock speeds without overheating issues, particularly the i486DX2 which operated at twice the external bus speed. This allowed IBM compatible systems with the 486 to outperform Macintosh models significantly. Apple's decision to limit the use of the '040 to expensive Quadras while the 486 was more widely accessible to OEMs and enthusiasts exacerbated the situation. By late 1991, as Apple's high-end Macintosh desktops shifted to the '040, the company faced challenges in keeping up with the advancements in the industry.

Some hard rock bands from the 1970s and 1980s sustained successful recording careers. Bon Jovi's "It's My Life" from their double platinum album Crush (2000) was a commercial hit. AC/DC's Stiff Upper Lip (2000) went platinum. Aerosmith's Just Push Play (2001) reached platinum status and included the popular track "Jaded". Heart's Red Velvet Car (2010) marked their return to the Top 10 after a decade, making them the first female-led hard rock band with Top 10 albums in five decades. Bands like Van Halen, The Who, and Black Sabbath had reunions and tours during this period, along with a special performance by Led Zeppelin in 2007, reigniting interest in their music.

In order to mitigate the risk of mixing out-of-phase supplies, it is essential to maintain strict isolation between sections of the line that are fed from distinct feeder stations. This separation is ensured through the use of Neutral Sections, also referred to as Phase Breaks, which are typically installed at feeder stations and at intervals between them. Usually, only half of these Neutral Sections are active at any given time, with the remaining ones serving as backups to facilitate the shutdown of a feeder station and the transfer of power from neighboring stations. Neutral Sections generally comprise an earthed wire segment that is insulated from the adjacent live wires by materials like ceramic beads. This design allows the pantograph to transition smoothly from one section to another. The earthed segment acts as a barrier to prevent the formation of an arc between live sections, particularly when there is a voltage disparity between them due to different phases. In such cases, the protective circuit breakers may struggle to safely interrupt the high current flow.

Carolingian art was primarily created for a select group associated with the court, as well as the monasteries and churches they endorsed. It aimed to revive the grandeur and elegance of imperial Roman and Byzantine art while being influenced by Insular art from the British Isles. Insular art combined the vigor of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic ornamentation with Mediterranean forms like manuscripts, shaping artistic characteristics throughout the medieval era. Surviving religious artworks from the Early Middle Ages consist mainly of illuminated manuscripts and intricately carved ivories, initially crafted for metalwork that has since been lost. Artworks in precious metals held the highest prestige, yet only a handful remain intact, including notable pieces like the Cross of Lothair, various reliquaries, and discoveries like the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo, and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from Visigothic Spain, and Nagyszentmiklós near Byzantine.

Successful cotton cultivation necessitates an extended period without frost, abundant sunlight, and a moderate rainfall ranging from 600 to 1,200 mm (24 to 47 in). While soils typically need to be somewhat dense, the nutrient content does not have to be extraordinary. Generally, these requirements are found in the seasonally arid tropics and subtropics of both the Northern and Southern hemispheres. However, a significant amount of today's cotton is grown in regions with lower precipitation levels, relying on irrigation for water supply. Each year, production typically commences shortly after the prior autumn's harvest. Although naturally a perennial, cotton is planted annually to manage pests effectively. Planting times in the Northern hemisphere vary from early February to early June in spring. The region in the United States known as the South Plains is particularly renowned for its cotton production.

During Darwin's lifetime, the book underwent numerous translations, which encountered challenges in accurately conveying its concepts and metaphors, leading to potential biases reflecting the translators' personal agendas. Darwin himself provided copies of the book to individuals in France and Germany in the hope of finding competent translators, with the expectation that they would independently arrange for publication with local publishers. One notable translator, the esteemed naturalist and geologist Heinrich Georg Bronn, produced a German version in 1860 that incorporated his own interpretations, introducing contentious topics excluded by Darwin. For instance, Bronn substituted "favoured races" with "perfected races" and included additional essays on subjects such as the origins of life and a concluding chapter on religious connotations influenced by his commitment to Naturphilosophie. Following Darwin's feedback, Bronn issued a second edition in 1862 based on the third English edition, but tragically passed away from a heart attack. Subsequently, Darwin collaborated closely with Julius Victor Carus, resulting in an enhanced translation published in 1867.

During the Capetian dynasty's reign, France gradually expanded its control over the nobility, extending beyond Île-de-France to encompass more regions of the country in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, they encountered a formidable adversary in the form of the Dukes of Normandy. In 1066, William the Conqueror (duke 1035–1087) led the conquest of England (r. 1066–87), establishing a trans-channel empire that endured in different iterations throughout the Middle Ages. The Normans also colonized Sicily and southern Italy, following Robert Guiscard's (d. 1085) arrival in 1059 and the subsequent creation of a duchy that evolved into the Kingdom of Sicily. Under the Angevin dynasty of Henry II (r. 1154–89) and his successor Richard I (r. 1189–99), the English monarchs governed England and extensive territories in France, acquired through Henry II's family ties.

IGN rated the Xbox 360 as the sixth best video game console of all time in 2009 among 25 competitors. Despite not leading in sales during its generation, the Xbox 360 was recognized by TechRadar for its significant impact on the gaming industry by promoting digital media distribution and online gaming through Xbox Live, and introducing game achievement awards. PC Magazine hailed the Xbox 360 as a trailblazer for online gaming, demonstrating the success of online gaming communities on consoles. The introduction of the Kinect motion capture camera five years after the Xbox 360 launch was a game-changer, setting a sales record and prolonging the console's life span. Edge magazine ranked the Xbox 360 as the second best console of the years spanning from 1993 to 2013, highlighting its unique features such as a dedicated social network, cross-game chat, regular indie game releases, and superior versions of multi-platform games.

After his father Sviatoslav I's death in 972, Vladimir, who had been prince of Novgorod, fled to Scandinavia in 976 due to his half-brother Yaropolk's murder of their other brother Oleg and subsequent control of Rus. With the assistance of his relative Earl Håkon Sigurdsson, ruler of Norway, Vladimir raised a Viking army and recaptured Novgorod and Kiev from Yaropolk. As Prince of Kiev, Vladimir's significant accomplishment was the conversion of Kievan Rus' to Christianity, which commenced in 988. According to the Primary Chronicle, Vladimir made the decision to abandon traditional idol worship (paganism) of the Slavs in favor of a new faith. He dispatched trusted advisors and warriors as emissaries to various European regions to explore Christianity.

Galicia was relatively spared from the major conflicts of the war, being one of the regions where the initial coup succeeded, thus remaining under Nationalist control led by Franco's army throughout the duration of the war. Despite the absence of large-scale battles, the region experienced oppression and casualties: all political parties, labor unions, and Galician nationalist groups such as the Seminario de Estudos Galegos were dissolved. Galicia's autonomy statute was also revoked, similar to Catalonia and the Basque provinces once they were captured. According to Carlos Fernández Santander, a minimum of 4,200 individuals, including republicans, communists, Galician nationalists, socialists, and anarchists, were either extrajudicially executed or after hasty trials. Among the victims were the civil governors of all four Galician provinces, Juana Capdevielle (the wife of A Coruña's governor), and mayors like Ánxel Casal of Santiago de Compostela from the Partido Galeguista, as well as prominent socialists.

The majority of fatty acids are considered non-essential as the body can synthesize them as required, typically utilizing energy from other fatty acids. Nonetheless, in humans, two essential fatty acids are crucial and must be obtained through the diet. Maintaining a proper balance of omega-3 and omega-6 essential fatty acids is believed to be vital for overall well-being, despite a lack of definitive experimental evidence. These long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids, known as omega-3 and omega-6, are precursors for a group of eicosanoids called prostaglandins, which play various roles in the human body, acting as hormones in some capacities. Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), an omega-3 fatty acid, can either be synthesized from alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), an essential omega-3 fatty acid, or obtained from marine sources. EPA serves as a foundational element for series 3 prostaglandins, such as the mildly inflammatory PGE3. On the other hand, dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid (DGLA), an omega-6 fatty acid, acts as a precursor for series 1 prostaglandins.

The collegia appointed public priests who, upon election, gained enduring religious authority believed to be bestowed by the eternal divine. This authority granted them lifelong influence, privileges, and immunity. Consequently, both civil and religious laws placed restrictions on the number and types of religious positions that an individual and their family could hold. The religious laws, based on tradition and collegial practices, played a crucial role in shaping political decisions and had the power to override them, making it challenging for personal exploitation. Becoming a priest was considered an esteemed yet expensive honor, as priests in traditional Roman customs did not receive a salary. Offerings made to the deity belonged to the deity, requiring the priest to cover any deficits in public funding for the cult's needs, such as supporting assistants and maintaining the cult, from their personal finances. For individuals who had completed the Cursus honorum, a permanent priesthood was typically pursued or bestowed after a lifetime dedicated to military or political service, ideally both.

Beyoncé and Jay Z exchanged vows on April 4, 2008. She made their marriage public during a video presentation at the Sony Club in Manhattan on October 22, 2008, while celebrating the launch of her third studio album, I Am... Sasha Fierce. The album hit the shelves on November 18, 2008, in the US, unveiling Beyoncé's alter ego, Sasha Fierce, which originated during the creation of her hit single "Crazy in Love" in 2003. With a successful debut week, selling 482,000 copies, it claimed the top spot on the Billboard 200 chart, marking Beyoncé's third consecutive number-one album in the nation. Notable tracks from the album include the chart-topping "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)," along with the hits "If I Were a Boy" and "Halo," which also reached the top five. "Halo" emerged as Beyoncé's lengthiest-running Hot 100 single, bolstering her chart presence and further solidifying her status as a top artist in the US.

Darwin was deeply engrossed in his work on the comprehensive manuscript about Natural Selection when he was surprised with a package from Wallace on 18 June 1858. Wallace, who was situated in the Maluku Islands, enclosed twenty pages outlining an evolutionary concept in response to Darwin's earlier encouragement. He asked Darwin to pass it on to Lyell if he found it promising. The concept bore resemblance to Darwin's own theory, prompting Darwin to inform Lyell that his prediction had been exceeded, and he intended to offer to publish it in a journal of Wallace's choice. Darwin expressed concerns about the potential impact on his own original ideas. Lyell and Hooker proposed a collaborative publication combining Wallace's work with excerpts from Darwin's 1844 Essay and a 1857 letter to Gray to be presented at the Linnean Society. Consequently, on 1 July 1858, the joint papers were titled On the Tendency to conform to the Conditions of Existence.

In the wider urban area, 13% of the populace reside below the poverty threshold. As per a 2012 report presented by GHMC to the World Bank, Hyderabad is home to 1,476 slums accommodating a total of 1.7 million inhabitants, with 66% residing in 985 slums situated in the central area of the city, which constituted Hyderabad prior to the expansion in April 2007. The remaining 34% of the population live in 491 suburban settlements. Approximately 22% of households in the slums had relocated from various parts of India during the last decade of the 20th century, and 63% reported residing in the slums for over a decade. The overall literacy rate in the slums ranges between 60–80%, with female literacy standing at 52–73%. Basic service connections are available in one-third of the slums, while the rest rely on general public services provided by the government.
